demos.summary:
Author:NDTV Profit
Title:Zomato Joins Delivery Platforms Coalition To Drive Green Vehicles Adoption
Summary:- Zomato has joined the Deliver-E Coalition, an industry-led alliance of major food and grocery delivery platforms, to promote the global adoption of zero-emission two- and three-wheeler vehicles for deliveries.
- The Deliver-E Coalition, announced in Dubai and supported by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), includes founding members such as Delivery Hero, DoorDash, iFood, Mr D, Swiggy, Uber, and Wolt alongside Zomato.
- The coalition aims to accelerate the shift to electric vehicles, bicycles, and other zero-emission delivery options by sharing best practices, tracking electrification progress, and addressing common challenges.
- Anjalli Ravi Kumar, Zomato‚Äôs Chief Sustainability Officer, emphasized leveraging collective knowledge and action to speed up the transition to sustainable delivery methods.
- UNEP data highlights that global e-commerce sales reached $25 trillion in 2021, driving increased doorstep deliveries that contribute to rising urban emissions and operational pressures on cities and businesses.
- Without changes in last-mile logistics, urban delivery emissions in the top 100 cities are projected to increase by over 30%, leading to 14% more traffic congestion, 12% higher healthcare costs, and longer daily commutes by about five minutes.
- Research indicates that by 2030, deliveries could account for up to half of the transport sector‚Äôs emissions in urban areas.
- Since 2021, Zomato has committed to facilitating EV use among its delivery partners in India by raising awareness, enabling access to EV rentals through over 40 OEM and fleet partners, and advocating for supportive policies to reduce emissions and combat air pollution.
demos.reasoning:
- Content is highly relevant if the project concerns sustainable last-mile logistics, electric vehicle adoption, corporate sustainability initiatives, or urban emissions ‚Äî the summary directly addresses a major platform (Zomato) joining an industry coalition (Deliver-E) to accelerate zero-emission delivery modes.
- The item cites credible institutional backing (UNEP) and includes quantitative context (e-commerce scale, projected increases in urban delivery emissions and related impacts), which makes it useful for analysis, strategy, or advocacy work.
- It highlights concrete industry action (coalition membership, sharing best practices, measuring progress) and company-level commitments (Zomato enabling EV access through OEM/fleet partners), offering both policy and operational angles relevant to decision-making.
- Limitations: the piece is a news summary rather than a deep technical or policy paper, and it is somewhat India- and platform-specific; if the project is unrelated to sustainability/logistics or focuses on highly technical EV engineering, the applicability is lower.
- Overall, given strong topical fit for sustainability, urban transport, and corporate action, this is recommendable with moderate-to-high confidence.

demos.summary:
Author:ingokretzschmar
Title:Ingo Kretzschmar, CEO Thalia, √ºber Booktok, Innenstadtentwicklung und Gebrauchtbuchmarkt | Ingo Kretzschmar
Summary:Vom #BookTok -Hype bis Pre-Loved Books: Thalia im EHI Retail Insights Podcast üéôÔ∏è Heute ist meine Folge im Podcast EHI Retail Insights erschienen. Im Gespr√§ch mit Caroline Martens ging es um die besonderen Facetten des Buchhandels ‚Äì von Preisbindung und Remission √ºber unser Omnichannel-Modell bis zur Frage, warum Buchhandlungen heute mehr sind als Verkaufsfl√§chen: Orte der Entschleunigung, Begegnung und Inspiration. üìö Ein Thema, das mich begeistert: #BookTok . Wir als Branche haben lange √ºber Nachwuchs-Leserschaft nachgedacht ‚Äì und dann sorgt Social Media f√ºr den Hype, der Teens wieder in die L√§den zieht. Genau das sp√ºren wir t√§glich in unseren Buchhandlungen. Au√üerdem im Gespr√§ch: üìö Wie wir mit rund 570 Buchhandlungen (inkl. Partner) und einem stabil wachsenden Online-Anteil erfolgreich unterwegs sind. üìö Warum Events (zum Beispiel mit Vorbildern aus Sport und Kultur) Innenst√§dte beleben. üìö Wieso Gebrauchtb√ºcher und Kreislaufwirtschaft f√ºr uns strategisch wichtig sind ‚Äì mit Kundennutzen und Verantwortung gedacht. Danke an Caro Martens und das EHI Retail Institute -Team f√ºr den inspirierenden Austausch. Ich w√ºrde mich freuen, wenn ihr reinh√∂rt. üëâ Zur Folge: https://lnkd.in/ezC-7a5t
demos.reasoning:
- Content is directly relevant to retail, bookselling, and omnichannel strategy ‚Äî core topics for a project focused on retail insights or publishing industry trends.
- Authorship and context add credibility: CEO of Thalia speaking on an EHI Retail Insights podcast signals industry authority and actionable perspective.
- Topics covered (BookTok-driven demand, events revitalizing city centres, used-book strategy and circular economy, scale of store network and online growth) offer practical insights for marketing, merchandising, sustainability and urban retail planning.
- The post includes a link to a podcast episode for deeper learning, increasing its utility for users seeking in-depth content.
- Possible limitation: content is in German, so relevance depends on the user's language preferences and geographic focus; otherwise highly applicable.

demos.summary:
Author:TEXTILE VALUE CHAIN
Title:Brandenburg‚Äôs Textile Industry Embraces Circular Innovation
Summary:- Brandenburg is advancing a circular textile economy through a new policy paper titled ‚ÄúClosing the Loop in the Textile Industry: Value Creation in the State of Brandenburg,‚Äù developed from the TexPHB feasibility study funded by the Brandenburg Ministry of Climate Protection, aiming to integrate textile waste into new value chains and promote eco-innovation.

- The textile industry is highly resource-intensive and wasteful, with the EU producing 6.95 million tonnes of textile waste in 2020 and nearly 92 million tonnes globally ending in landfills or incineration annually; recycling polyester-blended waste from fast fashion and industrial textiles remains a significant challenge.

- Fraunhofer IAP, Beneficial Design Institute GmbH, and matterr GmbH collaborated on innovative methods to convert polyester-based textile waste into polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB), a biodegradable bioplastic, by recovering high-quality monomers terephthalic acid and ethylene glycol suitable for new polyester production and converting ethylene glycol into PHB using bacteria.

- The Beneficial Design Institute‚Äôs assessment supports establishing a textile innovation hub in Brandenburg to strengthen the regional circular economy, create new value chains, and improve sustainable textile waste utilization, with policy recommendations designed to guide Brandenburg decision-makers.

- PHB is a biodegradable, resorbable, and biocompatible bioplastic with ecological and economic benefits, applicable in geotextiles, erosion control, shoreline reinforcement, tree protection, and medical sutures, offering new market opportunities and fostering ecodesign collaboration among designers, scientists, and industry.

- The policy paper outlines a six-step strategic action plan to develop Brandenburg‚Äôs circular textile economy, aiming to retain regional value creation, generate qualified jobs, and position Brandenburg as a model region for the EU circular economy initiative, as emphasized by Clima State Secretary Dr. Haase.

- The study highlights cross-border collaboration potential with Poland and the Netherlands, enabling Brandenburg to lead in European circular economy efforts by advancing design-driven value chains and sustainable economic growth.
demos.reasoning:
1) Topic relevance: The summary addresses circular economy, textile waste valorization, and regional policy ‚Äî core topics for projects focused on sustainable materials, industrial ecology, or regional economic development. This makes the content highly relevant if the project's goals include sustainability, innovation in textiles, or policy-driven economic transition.

2) Technical substance: The summary provides concrete technical approaches (recovery of terephthalic acid and ethylene glycol from polyester blends, microbial conversion of ethylene glycol into PHB) and names research partners (Fraunhofer IAP, Beneficial Design Institute, matterr GmbH). That depth supports actionable insights for R&D, feasibility assessment, and technology scouting.

3) Economic and market implications: It highlights possible applications for PHB (geotextiles, erosion control, medical sutures) and potential for new value chains, job creation, and regional hubs. That makes it useful for business-case development, policy briefs, or funding proposals.

4) Policy and strategy relevance: The existence of a policy paper and a six-step action plan for Brandenburg, plus cross-border collaboration opportunities, is valuable to stakeholders planning implementation pathways or regional clusters.

5) Limitations and caution: The work is based on a feasibility study and lab-to-pilot concepts; scalability, cost-competitiveness, lifecycle impacts, and regulatory acceptance of PHB applications need further validation. If the project is narrowly focused on mature commercial tech or unrelated domains, relevance drops.

6) Overall judgment: Given the technical, economic, and policy information in the summary and broad applicability to sustainability and textile innovation projects, the content should be recommended for most projects with environmental, materials, or regional development focus.

demos.summary:
Author:World Footwear
Title:Fashion for Good launches new project to advance footwear circularity
Summary:- Fashion for Good has launched ‚ÄúThe Next Stride: Bio-Based Materials for Footwear Soles,‚Äù a 12-month collaborative project aimed at replacing fossil fuel-derived materials in shoe soles with bio-based polymers to reduce environmental impact.
- The initiative partners with major brands adidas, Target, and Zalando, alongside material innovators Algenesis Labs, Balena, Evoco, Kuori, and Yulex, focusing specifically on the sole, which constitutes at least 40% of a shoe‚Äôs mass and is primarily made from fossil-based polymers like PU, TPU, EVA, and rubber.
- The project seeks to validate high-performance bio-based alternatives through testing and external validation by SATRA, aiming to de-risk adoption and promote systemic change in the footwear industry by transforming the shoe‚Äôs most impactful component.
- adidas emphasizes the dual goal of sustainability and performance, with the project exploring whether bio-based materials can reduce environmental impact while maintaining or enhancing product standards expected by athletes and consumers.
- The findings will contribute to a comprehensive industry roadmap outlining steps for widespread implementation, including impact accounting, feedstock availability, and end-of-use solutions.
- Zalando highlights consumer demand for sustainable choices and positions material innovation as key to meeting this demand, with ‚ÄúThe Next Stride‚Äù setting new industry benchmarks by reimagining the shoe sole.
- The project represents a strategic collaboration to advance circularity in footwear by addressing the environmental footprint of soles, potentially influencing future material standards and sustainability practices across the industry.
demos.label: positive

demos.summary:
Author:Chris Dawson
Title:Refurbed raises ¬£44M, ahead of potential UK launch - ChannelX
Summary:- Refurbed, Europe's fastest-growing marketplace for refurbished electronics, household, and sports products, has raised ¬£44 million in its latest funding round led by investor Alex Zubillaga and Orilla, with participation from existing shareholders and advised by Stifel.
- The Vienna-based company plans to expand into the UK market, targeting a significant opportunity due to high demand for sustainable technology and a gap in reliable, high-quality refurbished tech options amid over 100 million unused phones in the country.
- In 2025, refurbed achieved double-digit EBITDA profitability, has been cash-flow positive since March 2025, and aims for nearly ¬£860 million in gross merchandise value for the fiscal year, driven by 40% year-on-year sales growth and AI integration.
- Co-founder and CEO Peter Windischhofer emphasized the alignment of profitability with sustainability, stating the company‚Äôs mission to make refurbished products mainstream while demonstrating strong financial performance.
- Investor Paco Riberas highlighted refurbed‚Äôs leadership in the refurbished category, rapid growth, profitability, and brand partnerships as key factors for long-term success aligned with responsible consumption values.
- Refurbed has processed 9 million devices and served 4 million customers across 12 European markets, leading in Germany and Austria, while achieving significant environmental impact by saving 350,000 tons of CO‚ÇÇ, 1,136 tons of electronic waste, and 116 billion liters of water.
- The company‚Äôs UK expansion aligns with national priorities such as Net Zero goals, Right to Repair legislation, and e-waste reduction targets, aiming to support sustainable consumer choices in the market.
demos.label: positive

demos.summary:
Author:Hugh Radojev
Title:Vestiaire Collective promotes internally for new chief executive
Summary:- Vestiaire Collective, a French luxury resale platform, has internally promoted its chief financial officer, Bernard Osta, to the position of chief executive.  
- Bernard Osta replaces Maximilian Bittner, the outgoing chief executive who led the company for seven years.  
- The leadership change was confirmed by Vestiaire Collective on October 6, 2025.  
- Maximilian Bittner has stepped down from the business, marking the end of his tenure as CEO.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Unknown Author
Title:Reboxed¬Æ and Olio Unite to Help People Rehome Their Tech
Summary:- Reboxed¬Æ and Olio, both certified B-Corps, have partnered to address e-waste by enabling UK residents to trade in and rehome unused tech, particularly phones, worth over ¬£20 billion currently idle in homes.
- The collaboration allows users to sell or recycle old devices directly through the Olio app, with Reboxed¬Æ refurbishing and reselling them, thereby saving an average of 50 kg CO‚ÇÇe per device and promoting climate action through everyday decluttering.
- Reboxed¬Æ offers tested, certified refurbished devices backed by a 24-month warranty, providing customers confidence in buying sustainable tech while unlocking value from unused gadgets via Olio‚Äôs platform.
- Olio‚Äôs community of 7 million users, known for sharing food and household items sustainably, now contributes to reducing e-waste by extending the life of tech products through Reboxed¬Æ‚Äôs Circularity-as-a-Service‚Ñ¢ platform.
- This partnership supports Reboxed¬Æ‚Äôs goal to rehome 100 million devices by 2030 and complements its existing collaborations with companies like Uswitch, Fonehouse, and Airtime Rewards, emphasizing collaboration as key to advancing the circular economy.
- Reboxed¬Æ co-founders Phil Kemish and Matt Thorne highlight the shared mission of making sustainability simple, social, and scalable, and describe circularity as a collective effort requiring integrated platforms and recommerce infrastructure.
- Consumers are encouraged to participate by visiting sell.reboxed.co or using the Olio app to trade in old phones, contributing to keeping technology in circulation and reducing environmental impact.
demos.label: positive

demos.summary:
Author:None
Title:Expand North Star at Dubai Harbour - Agenda 12 Oct 2025
Summary:- Expand North Star is a multi-day innovation and technology event held at Dubai Harbour, featuring a comprehensive agenda from October 12 to 14, 2025, with sessions focused on frontier innovation, AI, sustainability, education, and emerging technologies.
- The event includes a series of high-level panels, keynote addresses, and pitch competitions, such as "The Bold And The Talented: The UAE as a Hub for Frontier Innovation," the SUPERNOVA Pitch Competition for Sustainability Leaders, and discussions on scaling sustainability across the Arab region.
- Key topics covered include enterprise AI applications, cross-border trade innovations, digital twins, AI in education and talent management, cybersecurity economics, quantum computing, and synthetic data for AI growth, presented by global CEOs and experts from countries including the UAE, Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, UK, Korea, Switzerland, and more.
- The program highlights partnerships and launches, notably the "Go Solve!" initiative announced in collaboration with HP Inc and Sustain Labs Paris, aimed at fostering innovation and youth problem-solving.
- Sessions emphasize the UAE‚Äôs strategic role in innovation, including the introduction of a 2026 R&D tax incentive designed to financially support research and development, benefiting founders and investors by de-risking innovation spending.
- Sustainability and education are central themes, with panels addressing the transformation of sustainability education, youth microgrants for water crisis solutions, and AI-powered innovations in energy, led by prominent figures from organizations like HP Inc, INSEAD, ENGIE, and GEMS Education.
- The event offers diverse participation opportunities including startup exhibitions, investor programs, workshops, and networking spaces such as the Takeover Space at Hall 3, facilitating engagement among startups, scaleups, corporates, and investors.
- Expand North Star also features country and community partnerships, including Brazil as the 2025 Country Partner and The Firehood as Women in Tech Partner, underscoring its global and inclusive approach to frontier technology and innovation.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Si√¥n Lawrence-Geschwindt
Title:After reaching profitability, Refurbed secures ‚Ç¨50m to grow secondhand tech marketplace  ‚îÇ Impact Loop
Summary:- Austrian refurbished electronics marketplace Refurbed secured ‚Ç¨50 million in funding shortly after reaching profitability in March 2025, following ‚Ç¨2 billion in sales.
- The funding round was led by angel investor Alex Zubillaga, an early Spotify backer, and Orilla Asset Management, supported by the Riberas family; existing investors including Evli Growth Partners, Bonsai, Almaz, C4 Ventures, and Speedinvest also participated.
- Refurbed operates in 11 European countries, with Germany and Austria as its largest markets, and Sweden generating over ‚Ç¨200 million in sales since 2021.
- The company plans to use the new capital to enter additional markets, expand product categories, strengthen partnerships with brands such as Dyson, AEG, and K√§rcher, and enhance AI-driven tools to improve efficiency and sustainability.
- Refurbed‚Äôs business model is commission-based, taking approximately a 10% cut from each product sale, with the remainder paid to partner refurbishers.
- The global refurbished products market is projected to reach $118 billion by 2032, with Refurbed competing primarily against Germany‚Äôs BackMarket and Finland‚Äôs Swappie in Europe.
- Co-founder Peter Windischhofer emphasized the company‚Äôs focus on combining scalability with long-term profitability, contrasting with many firms that prioritize growth at the expense of capital efficiency.
demos.label: positive

demos.summary:
Author:Unknown Author
Title:Market Update: October 2025 | Circular Economy News
Summary:- France implemented the Anti Fast-Fashion Regulation on October 1, 2025, introducing a ‚Ç¨5 eco-tax on fast-fashion items that will double to ‚Ç¨10 by 2030, while Germany‚Äôs six industry associations are collaborating to develop an Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) system tailored for their market.
- The UK Fashion and Textile Association (UKFT) launched the National Textile Recycling Infrastructure Plan aiming for a circular textile economy by 2035, providing practical guidance on circular economy models.
- Key industry forecasts released include WGSN‚Äôs A/W 27/28 Key Colours highlighting themes of interconnectedness, and Premi√®re Vision Paris‚Äôs Season & Colour Report for Autumn‚ÄìWinter 26/27, offering comprehensive seasonal insights.
- Canopy‚Äôs 10th Hot Button Report reveals that about 70% of global man-made cellulosic fibre producers are phasing out sourcing from ancient and endangered forests, accelerating the shift to sustainable alternatives since 2016.
- The Ellen MacArthur Foundation released a film showcasing circular business models in fashion, featuring brands like Arc‚Äôteryx, H&M Group, and Tapestry, emphasizing profitability without increasing production.
- In technology and e-commerce, Amazon launched an AI tool ‚ÄúHelp Me Decide‚Äù to assist shoppers, but research shows ChatGPT‚Äôs referral conversion rates lag behind affiliate links and search engines, indicating consumer trust in AI remains limited.
- Fifty fashion brands will debut shoppable virtual worlds on Roblox for World Fashion Week via VLGE, enabling creators to launch games without coding knowledge, contrasting with traditional agency costs ranging from $10,000 to $100,000.
- Luxury market updates include Kering‚Äôs 5% sales decline yet outperforming expectations, Herm√®s‚Äôs 13.3% rise in leather goods sales, and LVMH‚Äôs 14% stock surge despite challenges in fashion and leather goods sales; Kering, Herm√®s, and Richemont reported 4‚Äì6% growth.
- Material innovations gained attention with Taylor Swift wearing a Ganni x Cycora¬Æ dress made from Ambercycle‚Äôs recycled polyester, potentially boosting awareness of low-impact materials.
- Circ¬Æ partnered with H&M Group to launch products using Circ¬Æ polyester and TENCEL‚Ñ¢ Circ¬Æ and REFIBRA‚Ñ¢ technologies, debuting in A/W 2025 and S/S 2026 collections, with trials conducted in Bangladesh.
- Stella McCartney introduced plant-based feather dresses by start-up Fevvers at Paris Fashion Week SS26, aligning with the trend of leather-like materials in fashion.
- India launched Liva Reviva‚Ñ¢ M, a next-gen circular fibre made with up to 50% mechanically recycled post-consumer textile waste, certified by Global Recycle Standard and Forest Stewardship Council.
- The European Circular Textile Coalition was formed by Reju and multiple partners to promote a fully circular textile economy in Europe, advocating for EU investment in systems that convert post-consumer textile waste into economic and environmental benefits.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Martine Denoune
Title:Comment fonctionne la revente de billets chez Transavia France?
Summary:- Transavia France launched a ticket resale platform three months ago, a unique service among European low-cost airlines, developed in partnership with French startup Fairlyne to enable customers to resell their airline tickets if they can no longer travel.
- The resale service is accessible directly through Transavia France‚Äôs digital channels, allowing eligible ticket holders to request resale of their booking under certain conditions, providing a simple and secure process without intermediaries.
- The resale technology, developed by Fairlyne, integrates seamlessly in white-label mode with Transavia‚Äôs systems, enabling customers to resell tickets via the usual Transavia website or through resale.transavia.com up to one hour before the flight.
- When a ticket is purchased by another traveler, the original buyer receives partial financial compensation, including at least a full refund of airport taxes and up to 50% of the total ticket price, with the transaction incurring a fee but generally less costly than traditional airline refunds.
- This resale innovation helps Transavia optimize seat utilization and generate additional ancillary revenue from services such as seat selection, priority boarding, baggage fees, onboard sales, and refreshments.
- Nicolas H√©nin, Deputy General Manager for Commercial & Marketing at Transavia France, highlights that the service improves customer experience and operational efficiency, aligning with the airline‚Äôs commitment to responsible innovation.
- The resale platform can be accessed at https://resale.transavia.com/, offering a convenient option for passengers unable to travel to recover part of their ticket cost.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Elsa Wenzel
Title:VF Corporation hits 61% traceability for key materials
Summary:- VF Corporation has achieved 61% traceability by volume for five key materials‚Äîwool, leather, natural rubber, synthetics, and cotton‚Äîwith wool leading at 78% and leather at 67%, aiming to trace all these materials to the commodity level by 2028 as part of its sustainability efforts.
- The company reduced its Scope 3 emissions by 7% in 2024 compared to 2023 through increased use of preferred and regenerative materials and lower production volumes, though its overall emissions remain 19% above the 2017 baseline.
- In 2024, VF sourced 5,003 metric tons of its key materials through regenerative practices, with significant progress including 94% regenerative cotton supply, 64% recycled synthetics surpassing 2026 goals, 75% leather traceability, 74% natural rubber traceability, and 87% wool traceability with 94% ZQ-certified wool.
- VF began traceability initiatives in 2017, expanding from 10 to 100 products by 2021, and now conducts extensive supply chain audits (1,070 in 2025), publicly sharing supplier data for 1,214 suppliers mainly in Asia-Pacific, Americas, and Europe to monitor environmental and social risks.
- Circular design and resale programs remain a small part of VF‚Äôs business, with The North Face Renewed selling 96,000 secondhand items in 2024, compared to hundreds of millions of new products sold annually.
- Raw materials account for 79% of VF‚Äôs climate footprint, with polyester (25%), leather (19%), and cotton (18%) as major contributors; VF‚Äôs science-based targets include net zero by 2050 and near-term goals to reduce Scopes 1 and 2 emissions by 55% and Scope 3 by 33% by 2030 from 2017 levels.
- Despite progress, watchdog group Stand.earth criticizes VF for not being on track to meet its 2030 supply chain emissions reduction target, though it acknowledges improvements in regenerative cotton use and material traceability to Tier 5.
- VF‚Äôs 2025 revenues declined nearly 4% to $9.5 billion amid workforce reductions, including the departure of its Senior Director of Sustainability, but the company asserts that sustainability initiatives continue actively.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Nicole Silberstein
Title:Cond√© Nast Taps Ebay as Official Pre-Loved Partner in Bid to ‚ÄòReshape Circular Fashion‚Äô - Retail TouchPoints
Summary:- Cond√© Nast and Ebay have formed a multi-year partnership designating Ebay as the official Pre-Loved Partner across Cond√© Nast‚Äôs major U.S., UK, and German publications, including Vogue, GQ, Vanity Fair, Wired, Architectural Digest, Teen Vogue, and Glamour, to promote pre-loved and circular fashion.
- This collaboration builds on prior joint efforts such as events at the Met Gala, Vogue World in Paris, Hollywood, and London, and the Vogue Vintage Market, with the Ebay x Twiggy campaign winning a Luxury and Lifestyle Cannes Lions award in 2023.
- The partnership aims to deepen integration at key cultural moments and expand storytelling around sustainable style and authenticated resale, with plans to extend beyond fashion and luxury sectors.
- Ebay is actively working to maintain its leadership in the competitive secondhand fashion market, which now includes rivals like ThredUp, Poshmark, Rebag, Etsy, TikTok Shop, and Facebook Marketplace.
- To enhance its appeal, Ebay has appointed celebrity stylist Brie Welch as Resident Stylist, launched the Ebay Watchlist fashion trend report, introduced consignment and authentication services, and advocated for a Recommerce Day holiday supported by Alicia Silverstone.
- Ebay has also hosted high-profile events such as a charity sale featuring Elton John‚Äôs wardrobe and launched Pre-Loved Fashion Shows at New York and London Fashion Weeks to elevate the profile of secondhand fashion.
- Executives from both companies emphasize the partnership‚Äôs goal to reshape circular fashion by making pre-loved items aspirational and sustainable, inspiring new generations to embrace vintage and authenticated fashion as a form of personal style.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Dominique Jack
Title:Get food as low as $4 from restaurants, bakeries, and more with phone app
Summary:- Too Good To Go is a Danish-founded organization and app that connects consumers with surplus food from restaurants, bakeries, supermarkets, and other establishments at prices as low as $4, aiming to reduce food waste.
- Users in New York City can purchase meals or surprise bags containing leftover or surplus food items through the app, then pick up their orders within a specified time frame.
- Surprise bags may include a variety of foods such as forgotten pickup orders, bakery goods, pizza slices, garlic knots, and grocery items, some of which may be past their ‚Äúsell by‚Äù date but remain safe to eat.
- The company launched in Copenhagen in 2015 and has since expanded to 19 countries, accumulating over 100 million users worldwide.
- The app offers an affordable way for consumers to access fresh food while supporting sustainability efforts by preventing edible food from being discarded.
- Dominique Jack, a digital content producer with PIX11 since 2024, reported on this initiative, highlighting its local availability and impact.
- For more information or to download the app, users are directed to the Too Good To Go website or app store listings.
demos.label: negative

demos.summary:
Author:Unknown Author
Title:ThredUp Report Reveals 40% of Holiday Budgets Will Go to Secondhand Gifts
Summary:- ThredUp‚Äôs 2025 Holiday Report, based on a survey of 2,000 consumers by GlobalData, reveals that despite economic uncertainty, consumers plan to allocate nearly 40% of their holiday budgets to secondhand gifts, up from the usual 30% spent on resale in everyday shopping.
- Over half of shoppers (52%) intend to maximize value by purchasing more items for less money, and 51% plan to start holiday shopping earlier to be more strategic with their spending.
- Secondhand gifts are increasingly preferred, with 66% of all consumers open to giving them, rising to 80% among Millennials; key motivations include saving money or getting better value (62%) and finding unique, one-of-a-kind items (56%).
- Nearly 47% of respondents plan to or are considering selling their own items, such as apparel, electronics, and luxury goods, to fund holiday gifts, a trend especially prevalent among Millennials (70%) and Gen Z (57%).
- The most popular secondhand gift categories are accessories (40%), women‚Äôs apparel (36%), and vintage items across apparel, accessories, and home goods (31%).
- ThredUp emphasizes that secondhand gifting carries emotional value by offering unique or nostalgic items with stories, which can be more meaningful than new products.
- ThredUp positions itself as a leading online resale platform, leveraging proprietary technology and a Resale-as-a-Service model to facilitate buying and selling secondhand apparel, shoes, and accessories, promoting sustainability and extending the lifecycle of clothing.
- The full 2025 Holiday Report is available for download, providing detailed data and insights on resale trends shaping the holiday shopping season.
demos.label: positive

demos.summary:
Author:None
Title:The wellbeing framework for consumer experiences in the circular economy of the textile industry
Summary:- The paper argues that integrating human wellbeing with the material lifecycle of garments can help reduce textile consumption and support a successful Circular Economy (CE) in the textile industry, emphasizing consumer behavior as a critical factor despite broader systemic sustainability challenges.

- It highlights the problem of overconsumption driven by fast fashion, noting that UK and EU consumers use over 25 kg of textiles annually‚Äîtwo to three times the global average‚Äîwith clothing comprising over 60% of this, underscoring the urgency of rethinking consumption patterns.

- The Textiles Circularity Centre aims to develop new supply chains and consumer experiences that transform post-consumer textiles and waste into renewable materials, while this paper seeks to clarify the concept of wellbeing in circular textile consumption to guide future product and service design.

- Wellbeing is conceptualized holistically, combining hedonic (short-term pleasure) and eudaimonic (long-term meaningful living) aspects, with an interdisciplinary, phenomenological approach that situates individuals, society, and environment as interconnected, moving beyond simplistic or purely economic views.

- The paper identifies a significant gap in CE research regarding consumer roles and consumption models, noting that only 19% of CE definitions include consumption, despite consumers being central to product longevity, reuse, and disposal, and critiques current sustainability metrics like Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) for neglecting multidimensional wellbeing impacts.

- It discusses the complexity of consumption, historically viewed through various lenses including conspicuous consumption, identity expression, and economic growth, while also acknowledging negative consequences such as environmental degradation, social alienation, and health issues, and the challenge of changing consumer behavior given material goods‚Äô role in identity and meaning.

- Existing consumer behavior change strategies relying on information, moral appeals, or sacrifice have limited effectiveness; instead, the paper suggests that promoting wellbeing dimensions such as enjoyment, self-expression, and community engagement may better support sustainable consumption aligned with circular economy goals.

- The paper critiques the dominance of hedonic wellbeing linked to consumerism and fast fashion, proposing alternative frameworks like Alternative Hedonism that emphasize pleasure in sustainable consumption, and calls for mobilizing a holistic notion of wellbeing to create attractive, viable circular consumer experiences within capitalist systems.
demos.label: negative

signature.instructions:
Analyze the text and determine if it should be recommended to user based on the project context.
Output a recomendation score between 0.0 and 1.0, where 1.0 is highly recommendable.

fields.description: The ID of the project this content belongs to. Relevance context depends on this.
The summary of the content to evaluate.
Step-by-step analysis of why this is relevant or not.
A float score between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating probability of being recommended.
